caption:
A diagram of the region $D(\mathbf{s})$ in the image domain $\Omega$. One can think of the individual gradients $
abla I_{i}(\mathbf{s})$ as observations of the underlying gradient of the image surface $
abla I(\mathbf{s})$. % Is this a good idea For the local linearisation to be valid between $I_0$ and $I_2$, the gradient must be constant along the dotted line. To assess the validity of the linearisation, we can look at the gradients $
abla I_{0}(\mathbf{s})$, $
abla I_{1}(\mathbf{s})$ and $
abla I_{2}(\mathbf{s})$; if any of these gradients are different, then the linearisation is invalid.
